mainmatter.p: Let (X, \le ) be a poset. A subset A \subseteq X is upwards-closed if it satisfies \forall a \in A. \ \forall x \in X. \ a \le x \rightarrow x \in A.
Let D be an algebraic dcpo and U \subseteq D a Scott open subset. We then have U = \bigcup \{ { \uparrow } c \mid c \in U, c \ \mathsf{compact} \} .

block.headline: Proof.
block.p: ( \impliedby ) This direction follows directly from the upward closure of U, which is entailed by its Scott openness.

( \implies ) Let x \in U. We need to show that there exists a compact c \in U such that x \in { \uparrow } c. Thanks to the algebraicity of D, we know that x = \bigvee ^{ \uparrow } \{ c \in \mathcal{K} (D) \mid c \sqsubseteq x \} . The fact that U is Scott open entails it is inaccessible by directed joins so the fact that \left ( \bigvee ^{ \uparrow } \{ c \in \mathcal{K} (D) \mid c \sqsubseteq x \} \right ) \in U means there exists a compact c_0 \in U with c_0 \sqsubseteq x which is to say x \in { \uparrow } c_0.

frontmatter.title: Scott open subset of a dcpo

mainmatter.p:
Let (D, \sqsubseteq ) be a dcpo. A subset U \subseteq D is called a Scott open if it satisfies the following conditions.
U is upwards-closed.
U is inaccessible by directed joins, which is to say for any directed subset S \subseteq D, if ( { \bigvee }^{ \uparrow } S ) \in U then there is some x \in S such that x \in U.
The definition here follows the definition at the beginning of Section 2.2 of Mike Smyth's handbook chapter on topology.
